page.title: 02A walk on the downs - Lydden
page.content: In the late afternoon of July 3rd 1985 we walked a footpath along the North Downs just south of the main road between Dover and Canterbury.The previous winter had been bitterly cold, well below freezing,followed by an unusually wet June.This had delayed the growth of many plants,but the grass had flourished. The afternoon was warm and sunny and the footpath we followed crossed open downland.The ground below us was uneven.Most of it was planted with barley which was knee high.To the left was a hedgerow planted with oak,ash, elder and hawthorn. The wild roses,elder and blackberry were flowering.The downlands are a good hunting ground for wild flowers.On our brief walk we saw bladdercampion, forget-me-not,vetches,mayweed and poppies.
